Michigan Initial Health & Safety Training Module B
Section 1: Administration of Medications

What Can Child Care Programs Do?

Let’s discuss what child care programs can do to keep children safe from responses to food allergies.

Watch for side effects and adverse reactions

A list of potential side effects should be provided by the parents on the “Authorization to Administer Medications” form. Staff should be aware of, watch for these side effects, and react appropriately dependent on the severity of the side effects. Parents should always be notified.

Lock medications in a cabinet away from children

If a child has emergency medications ordered they should be readily available when the child is outdoors and always taken when the child is on a field trip. Examples of this would be an asthma inhaler or injectable epinephrine.

Emergency meds available outdoors/field trips

A list of potential side effects should be provided by the parents on the “Authorization to Administer Medications” form. Staff should be aware of, watch for these side effects, and react appropriately dependent on the severity of the side effects. Parents should always be notified.

Wash hands before and after administering meds

Always wash your hands before and after administering medications. Washing before prevents contamination of medications. Washing after prevents residual fragments of the medication being transmitted.
